thread.title: H.S. football: Indian Hills beats Lakeland, 3-0, on Matean Sedaghat field goal - Sports
thread.title_full: H.S. football: Indian Hills beats Lakeland, 3-0, on Matean Sedaghat field goal - Sports - NorthJersey.com

author: JIM McCONVILLE
title: H.S. football: Indian Hills beats Lakeland, 3-0, on Matean Sedaghat field goal - Sports
text:
OAKLAND – Despite all of the offensive fireworks in the first three games, Indian Hills knew that to get to 4-0 for the first time this century, the defense was going to have to command the day.
With the rain and wind providing a dreary backdrop, the Braves went out and did exactly what they needed to do. They made a 25-yard first-quarter field goal by Matean Sedaghat stand up in a 3-0 win over the Lancers.
As the emotional exuberance of the win set in, Indian Hills coach Joe Sabella praised his defense.
“We said all week long leading up to this, bend but don’t break, and I think that’s what we were able to do,” he said. “They had some drives, but we never faltered, never let up the big play and kept them out of the end zone.”
The Lancers (2-2) got inside the Braves’ 30-yard line only twice, with both drives ending on fourth-down incomplete passes that were knocked away by Trevor Spitaletta (first quarter) and Ryan Janiga (5:59 left in the game).
Indian Hills also was able to contain Lakeland quarterback Danny Mullin, who spent the majority of the game doing a wonderful impression of Fran Tarkenton, scrambling out of the pocket and slicing and dicing for yards.
Mullin had 103 rushing yards on 16 carries, but his longest gain was 17 yards. He was sacked twice and was pressured into a 4 of 17 passing effort for 56 yards.
“That was the focus all week,” Sabella said. “We knew there were going to be times he was going to make us pay, but it was about keeping him in the box, not letting him get the edge.”
The only score of the game came when the Braves were facing a fourth down on their 40-yard line and went with a fake punt. The pass went incomplete, but there was a roughing-the-passer penalty on Lakeland that extended the Indian Hills possession. Two plays later, Nick Wisnovsky found a crease off left tackle and went 33 yards to the Lancer 12. They stalled at the 8, but Sedaghat knocked the field goal through with 5:50 on the first quarter clock.
Indian Hills had another golden chance after a botched Lakeland punt set them up at the Lancer 7. On fourth down, Braves QB Tim O’Brien was stopped inches short of the goal line.
“I was thinking 9-0 at that point and being up two scores” Sabella said. “With the rain and wind I wasn’t sure about the field goal, but I was kicking myself at halftime.”
His defense picked him up and his offense, specifically wide receiver Derek Anderson, made his decision moot. After a first half that saw the two teams go a combined 0 for 14 passing, Anderson made a pair of solid catches to give his team field position.
The first was a 34-yard reception on third and 11 from the Hills 21-yard line. That drive ended in a fumble, but the Braves held on defense. After being buried at the IH 7-yard line off a punt, Anderson made an 18-yard grab on third-and-18 that helped Hills move into Lancer territory.
“I just had to catch the ball with my hands,” Anderson said. “I had one in the first quarter that I didn’t hold on to. It was about making the plays we needed to keep possession.”
